Maybe this is a question for a scientific theread rather than a religion forum. But I have wondered this for a long time.
 
 The story below prompts me to ask ...
 
 Why do scientists like to weigh on religious issues, so much? 
 
 Heaven is a 'fairy story', says Stephen Hawking
 
 If Hawking doesn't believe in heaven, fine. But why even make it a priority to attack it in the first place? It's a double standard for scientists to demand religion stay away from scientific matters, but then turning right around and weighing in on religious matters.
 
 It's a sad reality, but the bottom line is that the only reason Hawking has the audience he does (and I'd say even the respect he does) is because people feel sorry for him over his tragic disease. I don't mean that disrespectfully, but I believe it is true. In terms of his writings and views, they aren't anything particularly novel or earth shattering compared to many other scientists.

post_info.post_title: Why do scientists like to weigh on religious issues, so much?

 I think you're right about Hawkings, to an extent. The scientists who speak up on atheist issues, like Hawkings, Dawkins, Harris, do get more public exposure because of their atheist viewpoints, and they get respect for what they say because they are scientists. Stephen Jay Gould, on the other hand was among the best evolutionary biologists who ever lived, in my books he's second only to Charles Darwin, and he spoke up against creationism just as much as Dawkins does today. Yet, he didn't get nearly as much public attention as any of today's TV scientists (how many of you knew who Gould was before this?), he was just doing it 10+ years before anyone else was. He's the hipster of the scientific atheists. That doesn't mean Hawkings, Dawkins or Harris aren't good scientists, they've all contributed good things to science. They just happen to speak up against religion - as ATHEISTS, not scientists - and that gets them publicity.

Their own? Piltdown Man? Cold Fusion?

 
 You know what's cool? Science is what exposed the Piltdown Man hoax and the failure of Cold Fusion. 
 
 The announcement for Cold Fusion came before the paper was peer reviewed and the idea tested. Once this was done, science showed that it didn't work... It's only the big announcement and the media reaction that made it such a big deal. 
 
 Piltdown Man was thought to be a fraud when it didn't fit in with the other hominid fossils that were found, and proved with the introduction of fluorine absorption dating. 
 
 This is why science is referred to as being self correcting. Error may creep in, but it's never safe.

Like it or not, the Bible endorses slavery, and says that witches, homosexuals, adulterers, women who aren't virgins before marriage, blasphemers, and non-believers should be put to death. These were 'moral teachings' and Christian societies God's recommended actions for these offenses were a good way to go about punishing them. 
 
 
But other religions are still theistic. It's very odd to me that any atheist would argue on the basis of one religion over others, when you don't believe in ANY of them. The point is that it doesn't bode for your view, which is that there should be ANY religious experiences going on.

Then it's no longer Christian, now, is it?

 
 Well, since their actions were scriptural, I don't see why not. Are you saying that that Exodus 22:18 isn't largely responsible for the witch hunts? That the laws regarding slavery in the bible weren't responsible for the view that slavery was an institution of God?
 
 I know that modern Christians (thanks in large part to a mostly secular society) ignore these parts of the bible, but Christian societies in the past did not.
 
 
Since people started using it to justify irrational hatred of religion.

 
 No they use the irrational acts of religion to justify their criticism. Not all atheists care about religion at all (I would guess the majority do not, especially atheists in places like Scandinavia, where religion is not often forced on them).
